title: DXF and GCode- generator for involute gears

description.text:
This is adopted version of cliffords gear generator. Some format statements were changed, to run also on old versions of python, also the visual display part was removed.
Make the file executeable, and it should run on the slightly outdated ubuntu hardy, that is necessary to run the free cnc-controller software emc2.
geargen_hardy is just this version however, gearsgcode.py is an advanced script, that will also create a ngc gcode file.
it is parameterized.
It has cutter compensation enabled. Therefore, you need to have a valid tooltable in emc2. Also, you need to make the parameter #5 a little bit larger than the tool radius, so the initial move works.
If the tool radius is too large for the dents, emc2 will complain.
Also, it is recommended that the clearance specified via -c is larger then the tool radius, so there is no friction in the groves.

copy paste from clifford.
however, this versions will automatically write default.dxf if no file is specified.
also, a gcode file is created Usage example:
python gearsgen.py -n 5 -m 1 -c 0.5 -f mygear.dxf Help message as generated by 'python gearsgen.py --help': Usage: python gearsgen.py [ options ] Options: -i ....... generate outline for internal gear
(this means the meaning of pitch and clearance
is inverted the sign of the spacing is changed) -n N ..... number of teeth (default = 5) -m U ..... module (default = 1.0)
(for gears to mesh, their modules must be equal. the gears
working diameter is [number of teeth] times [module]) -c X ..... clearance (default = 0.0)
(move the gear bottom land down by this number of milimeters) -a X ..... addendum offset (default = 0.0)
(move the gear top land up by this number of milimeters by
incrasing the addendum by this value. use with care!) -p X ..... pitch (default = 0.0)
(move the gear top land up by this number of milimeters by
linearly extending the top land. do not confuse with '-a'!) -s X ..... spacing (default = 0.0)
(move the flanks inside by this number of milimeters.) -e ....... generate only DXF entities without DXF header or DXF footer
(usefull for creating larger dxf files from a script) -l T ..... name of the DXF layer for generated entities
(without this option, no layer information is added to the DXF) -x X ..... add this value to all X-coordinates in the generated DXF file
-y X ..... add this value to all Y-coordinates in the generated DXF file
-r X ..... rotate the generate wheel by this ange in degrees
(this can be used together with -e and -l to generate more complex
DXF files from scripts. default oriantation is gear at 0/0 with
a bottom land facing to the positive x-axis) -f T ..... name of the DXF file to generate
(without this option, a (tk) window is opend and the generated gear
is displayed. note that the gear is scaled to fit the viewport.) Argument types as used in abve options reference:
N = positive integer
U = unsigned decimal number
X = signed decimal number
T = text

remixed_from.title: Low Poly Snorlax - Prints without support! v1

description.text:
I loved roshandp1's pokemon chess set. But, I felt like it could be a lot cooler if the pawns were all higher level pokemon. I found files for Arbok, Pidgeot, Snorlax, Ditto, Arcanine, Lapras, Gengar, and Onyx, scaled them down to fit on top of the pawn. All freeCAD source files for the pawns are included in the files. I also included the chess board and box, courtesy of 1sPiRe, that I printed to have a full Chess Set. I wish I would have done this to Aftorres's version, but I found after I had finished.

For one full set:
(Color One)
1 - King Mew
1 - Queen Pikachu
2 - Bishop Bulbasaur
2 - Knight Charmander
2 - Rook Squirtle
1 - Pawn Ditto
1 - Pawn Snorlax
1 - Pawn Gengar
1 - Pawn Lapras
1 - Pawn Arcanine
1 - Pawn Onyx
1 - Pawn Pidgeot
1 - Pawn Arbok
2 - Corner Pieces
12 - Edge Pieces
18 - Center Pieces
1 - Box Lid

(Color Two)
1 - King Mewtwo
1 - Queen Pikachu
2 - Bishop Bulbasaur
2 - Knight Charmander
2 - Rook Squirtle
1 - Pawn Ditto
1 - Pawn Snorlax
1 - Pawn Gengar
1 - Pawn Lapras
1 - Pawn Arcanine
1 - Pawn Onyx
1 - Pawn Pidgeot
1 - Pawn Arbok
2 - Corner Pieces
12 - Edge Pieces
18 - Center Pieces
1 - Box Bottom

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Delta

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1 mm or smaller for pawns

Infill:

5%

Notes:

Some of the pawns need support! In particular Pidgeot, Onyx, Arcanine's tail, Gengar's arms, and Arbok's head. I recommend using your slicing software to do so. I tried to add some myself, but they aren't great. Also, I used a 0.2mm nozzle instead of the 0.5 mm one I started with. Definitely recommend smallest nozzle possible, as there is a lot of tiny details in the pawns.

Thank you's

Thank you to everyone who put their pokemon designs online. It made my job super easy, well relatively easy. Also, a huge thanks to roshandp1 and 1sPiRe who created super cool chess designs for everyone to download and print!

title: Low-Poly R2D2 and C3PO

description.text:
I would love to keep sharing my projects with all of you. If you enjoy with my designs, I invite you to become a patron, you will get early access to my designs and exclusive content! Also, you can help with a small donation.

Patreon: http://www.patreon.com/flowalistik
Donations: http://www.paypal.me/flowalistik

Single extrusion version of Low-Poly R2-D2 and C-3PO. Dual extrusion version and source files also available.

These models are divided in two/three parts. As all my low-poly designs, it doesn't need support material to be printed (I consider support material an evil creation of the Dark Side adepts).

Source files are available, which means you can easily remix this model or export in any other format.

I hope you enjoy with this model and may the force be with you!

description.text: This puzzle is 4x4x4 interlocking cube and is assembled using six parts. This means that it can only be assembled in one sequence and will not fall apart if moved. Once put together, all pieces become immobile except for the last puzzle piece in the sequence, making it the first piece to be removed when taking the puzzle apart. Our model demonstrates a few key mathematical concepts, specifically, sequences, proof by exhaustion, problem solving, and different geometries. As mentioned before, interlocking cubes only have one sequence for assembly. Due to the way the pieces interlock, the assembly requires specific motions and maneuvering of pieces for the cube to come to formation. The creation of these types of puzzles is fairly popular in the puzzle world, however, creating a new type of puzzle is very difficult. Often, the creation of a new interlocking puzzles has to be done by exhaustion, and they are typically fairly large as smaller puzzles have already been created. The use of logic and problem solving skills are required in both the creation of new puzzles, and the solving of existing puzzles. While both are rather difficult, once you have an understanding of interlocking nature, the assembly becomes more obvious. With the creation of each new cube, a unique geometric figure is created. It is unique in both the sense that all of the pieces are different and that the sequence for assembly uses different techniques.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX v2

Notes:

These pieces have a tendency to pop off of the bed if it is not warm enough, or melt if it is too hot. We found that 87º was a good medium, and with plenty of hairspray, the pieces printed just fine. For the final tower, to prevent warping, slow the printer down to around 30% speed.

ALSO: We printed the puzzles in the photos using 150% scaling.

This cube was based off of Thingiverse user richgain's model "Printable Interlocking Puzzle." Using his 6 piece puzzle design, we used Rhino to create our version of the puzzle. This involved creating rectangular prisms and using the Boolean Union function in the program. After printing a test-run, we quickly realized that our design did not account for the space necessary between each piece in order for the puzzle to fit together properly. In order to fix this problem, adjustments were made to our design by creating larger gaps in each piece of the puzzle. This was accomplished by using the Wire Cut function in the program to shave 1-2 millimeters off of every gap on each piece.

This is simple file handle suitable for small needle files with 3.5mm handles.

The handle is 50mm long and 11mm diameter.

I made this because most of the ones on Thingiverse were too big for my liking.

If the hole is too small when printed, just use a cordless drill running in reverse with a 3-3.5mm drill as required.
Don't run the drill forwards as this will cause it to 'grab' and you'll probably end up with a misaligned hole or injury.

Print this on a raft or brim with 3 perimeters and 25-35% infill

Solves the dilema of where to tuck one's hose away safely. Girls do not like to disconnect hosepipe fittings, and so it is easier to create a tap-like holder for the hose to nest in, where it can be used for rinsing hands and tools. 
The tap in our garden is at watering can level anyway, so repositioning the end of the hose makes it easier to wash tools off etc. without cricking your back. As the water flow is usually slow when you do this to avoid soggy sleeves, the kink in the hose doesn't seem to matter much.
Also, you now know where to find the damn thing!

This one was printed in the Gold/Brass effect PLA from Diamond Age Solutions Ltd., to make it look more like a rough-cast brass fitting. It is secured to the wall with two screws, which should have been brass to complete the effect, but you know...
The default STL and OpenSCAD files have a 25mm (approx. one American inch) tapered hole in it for a brass adjustable hose nozzle to fit in.
The angle of the holder still allows the nozzle to be inserted and removed without ramming it through the wall, despite appearances!

comments.text: The kink in the hose is almost definitely going to break the hose a lot sooner if you leave it like that.

My wife likes playing Moose Farkle and Penguin Farkle, a game of six dice in which the one is replace by the animal, and she asked if there was a Kitty Farkle. Until today, there wasn't. I grabbed a cat cartoon she had drawn on a post-it on the fridge door, turned it into an .stl and slapped it onto a dice model. Print 6x -- in Resin for extra weight -- push some sugru into the pip cavities, and BOOM. Kitty Farkle. Giving it to her in a nice wooden box for Christmas.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/lCQvDx3mXkN

Printer Brand:

Formlabs

Printer:

Formlabs Form 2

Modifed a standard die design with Tinkercad

Modified Dice .stl replacing the "one" pip with a cat. The cat was drawn by my wife, I made a high contrast image of her line drawing and filled in the negative space. That meant I had to do some inversion where the arm crossed the body and the whiskers extended past the face. I uploaded the image at Selva3D and converted it into an .stl file, then imported that into Tinkercad. Converted it to a hole and sunk it to the same depth as the pips.

Printed the resulting file in standard white resin with Omni's Hub in Boxtel (Highly recommend!) and then applied royal blue Sugru to the pip cavaties. Had to work reasonably fast to finish 8 dice before the Sugru set.

title: Digmesa FHKSC Flow Sensor Mounting Base

description.text:
Mounting base for FHKSC Flow Sensor Model #932-952x/Bxx, manufactured by Digmesa AG. This flow sensor is typically used in Espresso Coffee Machines to measure the amount of water dispensed by the machine.

The datasheet for the flow sensor is here: http://www.digmesa.com/wp-content/uploads/932-952x_Bxxx_GB_20V-2.pdf

This has 2 countersunk holes and a flat base for mounting (could be fixed with single, double screw or adhesive). The sensor is intended to push fit in and locate in two possible orientations on the top surface.

The sensor mounting holes are 12mm apart and 4mm and 2.85mm diameter, and the top plate 2.5mm thick. The mounting holes are 20mm apart and 3mm diameter. Overall height is 9mm (conservative minimum). There's a gap underneath for routing cables.

remixed_from.title: Cubistand Pencil Pen Brush Holder Stand

description.text:
I really like the simplicity of the cubistand pen holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1294085), but I thought I could like it better if I could adjust it to have more or less holes, and why not, decide the size of the hole. So I went ahead, and modeled it on openscad, and here's the result. You may generate the following pieces with this cutomizer:
Cubistand_main.stl
Cubistand_base.stl
Cubistand_rod_cap.stl
Only you will have to make your own rod

Corners look weird on the customizer screen, however on the stl generated they look nice and smooth. I haven't printed any yet, but presume it should print all right. If you jump into any issues when printing, please let me know.

title: PG1050 Battery case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I needed a case to protect my spare action cam battery during travel etc. so desugned this simple case.

It is designed for a battery marked Model: PG1050 - a Li-ion battery pack of 3.7V and 1050mAh (3.885 Wh)

The battery just clips in, no loose catches etc. required. I found that bending the sides in slightly while it was still hot from the heated bed worked very well to get the tension just right.

Hope you find it useful.

author: RGN01

description.text: this is a model for a full size table that i had designed to be made in bamboo https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XUmu_xiiwMI http://hackaday.com/2013/12/04/crab-ble-a-table-that-walks/#more-108937

print all the parts at 0.25 mm layer height using a .4 or less nozzle.. the  parts are interconnected using a m3 threaded rod and nuts ... the battery holder is mounted in the center..  
print 6 sets of the leg set and 2 sets of the cross brace set..  
for anybody interested in making it i woulf be making a detailed assembly diagram.  
the motors are optional .. the model can be moved manually also if needed..   i used 1:100 ratio 6v geared dc motors....   
also a lot of plastic lubricant is needed and it tends to jam up  
the legs are joint together using m3 x 12 mm hex nut and bolt
you need brass or pcb spacers of 5 or 5.5 mm for the leg pivots... also to mount the motors you need a 6x3mm pipe cut to length to clamp the motor mounts on

comments.text: Awesome model! One question. I am confused what the large holes in the pivots on the legs are for. Shouldn't they also be M3 sized holes?  I have studied the sketchup model. It shows larger holes but gives no explanation. So are the M3 bolts that connect the crankshaft triangles to the leg pivots, supposed to be loose? Any advice would be greatly appreciated.

comments.text:
http://s1003.photobucket.com/user/ted_026/media/Walking_table.jpg.html?sort=3&o=0
Small holes are circled in red. large holes in blue. Sorry for the bad microsoft paint photo.
comments.author: ekaggrat

comments.text: oh this , i forgot to mention .you need 5.5mm or 5mm pcb spacers or alternatively u can cut brass pipe of that diameter. basically it acts as a bush, without it everything will bind and have no movement... If you cant get any of those you can use printed  spacers that i have used in my holo clock design but you will need to add a lot of grease to make them smooth..

Adapter to use 24mm model rocket motors in a 29mm motor mount. Designed for use with reloadable casings, or single use motors, that have a thrust ring. Easy print, nothing fancy, the internal step in the main casing body is chamfered to help with overhang print quality. Does NOT work with Estes black powder 29mm motors with the cardboard cases.

Tested to fit with Aerotech or CTI 24mm cases, using an Estes threaded motor retainer. Other brands may not have enough thread depth. Printed on my Rostock Max V.2

Insert the main adapter body into the 29mm motor tube, insert 24mm motor into the adapter, and put the aft ring in place. Ridge toward the motor for Aerotech cases, and away from the motor for CTI cases. Then hold it all in with that Estes 29mm retainer.

All my prints have been with ABS, and the size was tweaked a bit after printing to make sure it fit. You may need to scale up a few percent if using PLA or if it comes out too small on the first try.
Made with 123d design

Vaporizer (for weed vaping)

These 3D print parts are based on my original wood version (shown in a photo).

Data points:
Optimal Temperature Range of heatblock for Vaping is 355 to 375 (F).
Depending on your soldering iron, time to Temp’s will vary ~ 8 min’s.
After several min’s of vaping, the Temp will rise to above 375F, UnPlug it (or use a controller such as your favorite Arduino design).
[FYI - I’m done vaping before it gets too hot so I don’t use a controller]

When assembled, all plastic is far enough away from the heatblock and won’t cause softening/melting (PLA or ABS or bottle).

The Parts:

Plastic Bottle - Boss ring is sized for a 4 inch Western Family water bottle but you can use most any bottle that meets the geometry (and / or scale the Boss’s X and Y dim’s as needed). 4 inch dia bottle keeps sides away from heatblock. Make cutout as shown in photo.

Bottle Cap - No 3d printers when I made the original so I used plastic from Ace Hardware (parts shown in photo). Sure, design/make your own…

The Boss - Tapered and radius’d to enable slipping the bottle on with ease via tilting it from the back and slipping the bottle’s cutout over the taper/radius’s. The bottle will tend to curl inwards due to the cutout so, the taper/radius is facing the soldering iron mount).

The Mount - Has an ‘Anti-rotation’ bump to limit the soldering iron from rotating. Press the Front cap into place - you can file/grind the nub if needed. Add a shim if needed… This will depend on the soldering iron. It will pull out from front entry so be sure it’s snug.

Mount Caps - Sized to fit without slop; be sure to file and sand the Mount and guts of the Caps so they install and remove without too much difficulty. Plastic shrink, Extrude Flowrate/etc will affect this so, experiment until you’re satisfied.
Install Rear Cap with the thicker wall facing the Front Cap (solder iron is tapered thus, so is the hole for it in rear cap).

Soldering Iron - Weller SP23L 25 watts. The concept is generic so, create your own parts for your/different solder iron… And, screw the heatblock onto the iron to ensure consistant heat transfer.

Heatblock - Original uses brass. New versions made for others use Alum 6061 (approx: 5/8” x 1.25” x 1.0”). No need for a recessed pocket like original brass one. Just drill the holes as shown in drawing. Better contact between Heatblock and Solder Iron means more responsive and uniform heating - better to under-size the hole and file it out as needed to make it snug.

[FYI - Resin builds up in bottle and hose - after 2 feet of hose length, most of the resin is cleared out of the hose… If concerned about breathing the resin, see the JAMA report cited below.

Good Vaping info here:
Health Info: From JAMA, the Journal of Amer. Med Assoc.
http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/1104848

Good Vape technical info (Temps, THC, CBD…) California NORML
http://www.maps.org/research-archive/mmj/Gieringer-vaporizer.pdf

author: Boblant

description.text:
These are a cosplay replica of the thumb blades worn by the character Narcisse in the film "Nightbreed."  
Because Narcisse is hilarious and "Nightbreed" is still awesome, that's why.  
The largest set of rings are 22mm ID; those with larger thumbs may need to CAD up a larger-diameter set.  
Actual pic coming once the gift-recipient sends me one.   
EDIT: added a pic of the final polished and painted prints.

Print either
2 hook.stl and 4 thumbrings, or 2 flathook.stl, 2 groovedplate.stl, and 4 thumbrings. The two options are for printing the hooks either flat or upright, depending on which is smoother on your printer. Assemble with cyanoacrylate, polish with acetone fumes or fine sandpaper, paint silver. You can bevel the edges with a Dremel if you want.

description.text: First of all, I am truly sorry about the rough work and bad communication skill to describe my creations. Most of my work are done by on going. Never really design it on paper but only concept in mind. However, since most of you guys are makers. It wouldn't be too hard to figure how to connect these joints and parts. There's no official way to hook them up. Or maybe the way I use is not the best way. You might came up much more brillant tricks to assemble it. I used a lots of 4-40/M3 bolts and aluminum tubing(exact like the image I attached in gallery) in size OD 3/16" and 5/32". Tube are used for reduce the firction in "supporting servo arms". Anyways, in this set I have used 11x 9G servos, 2x 10mm LEDs and mounts and use Arduino UNO with expansion shield to hook up electronic parts. About the programming I just put all servos in the loop from position 80~100 and it coincidentally looks like walking, even thou it's not the way I am going to make it walk. Haven't done the programming part yet. Again, sorry for rough design but it would be good experience for doing trouble shooting. (Don't bite me!) http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EBGnBat5wYM

For shouder and arm parts. You have to finish to assemble arms and shoulder first before connect shouder to body. I suggest you try to fit them first before you really tight them up on screw or whatever. This video shows the mistake I made. I shouldn't connect shoulder before complete the arm.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1OhjRVisuk4 In all STL files I only made one side for the reverse part, you just reverse the Y to -1 in your favor slicer application.

author: boquillas

description.text: A marble labyrinth that uses gears instead of cord-twisted rods for control. All parts for the labyrinth should be printable.

I realised that a gear rotate-extruded 180 degrees would work as the inner pivot for a marble maze. Any rotation of the outer axis (perpendicular to the inner rotation axis) will present the same face to the gear attached to the inner axis.  
I used my gear generator (thing:195160) to generate a gear with an angular pitch of 5mm and 20 teeth per circle (i.e. 9 + 2 * 0.5 teeth shown in a 180 degree rotated version). OpenSCAD was hacked slightly in the process of doing this to get a 360 degree rotation to work properly, so YMMV when using the included SCAD file.  
Models have been cleaned up using Repetier-Host v0.90D, so should be manifold and without intersecting triangles.

title: Oculus cv1 camera shelf clamp mount

description.text:
Oculus rift camera mount. Meant to clamp to a shelf like object with the camera hanging below. The camera is screwed onto a cylindrical part that rotates freely so you can adjust the aim of the camera. The clamp has a range of around 14mm to 25mm. The clamp base has M4 screw threads modeled into it, which worked fine for me, but took a fair application of force to get the screw started.

Prints in 3 parts, the clamp body, the sliding clamp bit, and a rotating bit that fits into the clamp body that you screw the camera onto.

Hardware required:
1 bolt to attach the camera. I used a 3/4", 1/4-20 UNC bolt.
1 M4 bolt to attach the sliding clamp bit to the clamp body. I used a 30mm M4 bolt.

description.text:
A Pantograph is a drawing aid that simplifies the enlarged copying of pictures or figures. It makes a great educational toy for families with children, or for people who are into craft activities like patchwork, woodworking, modelling, etc.

The Pantograph is shown set up for threefold expansion (note that when the set up is correct Arms A and C are parallel and Arms B and D are also parallel - you will know if it is wrong as it will not move). Pivots 1 and 2 are permanent and do not need to be undone. Pivots 3 and 4 are moved to select the magnification required ( x3, x4 or x5 ) - the nearer Pivot 2 is to the anchor point the greater the expansion.

Using the pantograph is simple. The drawing surface should be about 60cm square with the anchor point located in the bottom left hand corner and taped down. With the pantograph in its closed position, the picture to be copied is placed so that the tracing point (pivot 2) is just on the left hand bottom corner of the picture and the picture is then taped down. Place the blank drawing paper so that the pencil sits just on its bottom left hand corner. Move the pencil end so that the tracing point moves to the top right hand of the picture and ensure that the pencil is still on the blank paper. If so, tape down the drawing paper. Sometimes, depending upon the size of the picture, it may be necessary to overlap the the picture and drawing paper and copy the picture one half at a time.

Need a terminal block to splice up to 4 wires together but don't feel like making a trip to the hardware shop?  Just print your own in about 30 minutes.

I printed using solidest fill and finest detail.  
On the side with the clips, put a thin layer of blu tack along the middle of the inside of the block.  Then put big blobs in each of the 8 holes.  This is to keep the wires in position when you push the clip together.  
Once this is done put 4 small squares of aluminum foil between each pair of holes where the splice is to occur.  
Line up each pair of wires and push into position using a small screwdriver, then line up the other piece and clip the part together.  After a single use while developing this, the clips on my part snapped off but I was able to fix this with more blu tack.  
This is a pretty basic emergency cable splicing technique - can't really recommend it over $1 terminal block from the store ;-)

title: ROV Bilge Pump Shroud and Mount

description.text:
A system for mounting a bilge pump with a 49MM propeller to a PVC ROV frame. It mounts into a 1/2inch PVC tee fitting
The quill wedge uses a 1.25inch 10-24 flat head bolt and nut. The housing clamp uses a .75 inch 8-32 pan head bolt and nut.
This system would meet the requirements for MATE competitions where the propeller needs a housing.
The motor used is a Johnson Cartridge Bilge Pump 500 gallon per hour. Model 2855

description.text:
This work-in-progress is a 1:1 scale model of a 1U CubeSat based on the CalPoly rev13 design spec.available at http://www.cubesat.org
The top and bottom can be glued on. I left a hole in one of the ends to simulate a camera port. One of the sides is cutaway to allow visibility to the interior of the satellite.
The brown panel in the cutaway side was a scrap from a previous design and not included in the STL file.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

X3REX modified Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Sliced with Cura

Designed in Sketchup

Using the CalPoly rev 13 design spec as a reference, I created the digital design files in Sketchup.

ADDITIONAL NOTES:

The sides snap into the rails. The top and bottom are simply friction fit, but can be glued in place.
Ultimately I'll add circuit board mock-ups based on the PC/104 specification. I'll have to add some posts or standoffs to mount the boards on.

description.text:
This is a brain gear. Rotate one gear and they all spin.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0SV_UyZj2rA

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200

Infill:

20%
This was designed using an existing Brain Gear and a modified gear.  It was designed to be printed without support, using 45 degree angles.

• Print 12 P-Brain Gears
  • Print 5 Brain Gear links
  • Print 1 Brain Gear Link to base
  • Print 1 base
  • Assemble carefully using epoxy to bond links
  • Rotate and be amazed. :)

Project: P-Brain Brain Gear Overview & Background: This project will provide the opportunity to execute and learn basic printing techniques while printing a tangible object to interact with. Objectives: To learn plating. The 45 degree rule. Layer height and lamination. Part removal from build plate. Post printing assembly and finishing. Intro to gears. Audiences: 10 and up. Subjects: Math. Science. Math Art. Scientific Art. Mechanical Engineering. STEM. STEAM Skills Learned (Standards): Plating. The 45 degree rule. Layer height and lamination. Part removal from build plate. Post printing assembly and finishing. Intro to gears. Lesson/Activity: @200micron
  • Print 12 P-Brain Gears
  • Print 5 Brain Gear links
  • Print 1 Brain Gear Link to base
  • Print 1 base
  • Assemble carefully using epoxy to bond links
  • Rotate and be amazed. :)
    • Duration: 3 Days Preparation: You will need:
  • 1 3D printer.
  • 2 part Epoxy (JB-Weld works well).
    • You must start the project by ordering the color/s of filament you wish to use to print with. It is recommended that you use multiple colors for the gears to highlight them spinning. References: More information can be found for further study @
    http://reprap.org/wiki/BrainGear
Rubric & Assessment: A basic understanding of how a 3D printer can assist in Mechanical Engineering. Handouts & Assets: Class 3D printer and filament and curious kids.

comments.text: I did not use any support when printing this.  It was designed specifically not to require support.  The photo you see is printed in PLA.  I should mention that I print on glass with hair spray applied.
comments.author: funkshin

comments.text: Thanks for the info.   Have you ever tried it in ABS?
comments.author: funkshin

comments.text: FYI, warping (I assume this is what you mean by "curling") when printing with ABS is typically caused by either a bed that is not tight enough against the head for the first layer and/or not having a good surface (like hair spray on glass which works perfect for all filaments I have printed with) or it could be caused by not having an enclosed build area and the fast cool-down of ABS can cause warping.  If the first layer does not adhere good to the print surface ABS will warp just about every print.
comments.author: frubino

comments.text: I have never used ABS.
comments.author: frubino

comments.text: Admiring the quality of your prints....Did you run support on the gears and the link components?  I'm getting curling on the first 15 layers or so and adding support material just makes a mess at the contact points of the model.

print_settings.Notes:: Tokamak file will need to be printed twice (or with an additional copy for both halves). Ring file should be printed somewhere between three and six times in order to properly stand on the cylindrical base.

description.text: The Tokamak, from the Russian for “Toroidal Chamber with Magnetic Coils,” is a device that uses super-heated plasma and high-intensity magnetism in order to be used as a power source much like a nuclear reactor or a wind turbine. Mathematically, the Tokamak is a strong example of both theoretical and applied physics, vector fields, and advanced calculus. This isn’t really the type of manipulative that would be “played with” in a classroom setting, but it could definitely help students understand the movements of vector fields in a physics or higher math class that may focus on the parameterization of curves or contour integrals.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Tokamak file will need to be printed twice (or with an additional copy for both halves). Ring file should be printed somewhere between three and six times in order to properly stand on the cylindrical base.

Assembly

Both halves of the Tokamak, or main torus, will need to be glued together as well as each pair of ring halves depending on how many rings are printed. Heavy duty glue is recommended. It is important to remember that the half-spheres on each half-ring that serve as stabilizers be glued to the corresponding half-spheres so that all the pieces fit appropriately.

Creation Process

The tokamak was created via a combination of three separate Rhino files.
1.The toroidal chamber: This was created by cutting a section out of a torus, then partially filling the empty section with a smaller torus. Lastly, we sliced the torus in half for the purpose of printing properly on the print bed.
2.The outer rings: These were created by attaching a ring, a rectangular prism, and a sphere. The box on the bottom helps the ring sit flat on the base, while the sphere in the middle helps the ring fit into the torus and stay in one place. The rings were cut in half so that they could print easier.
3.The cylinder and base were created last.
No mathematical formulas, in particular, were used in order to create any of the objects in this model and its components.
NGSS CCSS

The Tokamak, from the Russian for “Toroidal Chamber with Magnetic Coils,” is a device that uses super-heated plasma and high-intensity magnetism in order to be used as a power source much like a nuclear reactor or a wind turbine. Mathematically, the Tokamak is a strong example of both theoretical and applied physics, vector fields, and advanced calculus. This isn’t really the type of manipulative that would be “played with” in a classroom setting, but it could definitely help students understand the movements of vector fields in a physics or higher math class that may focus on the parameterization of curves or contour integrals.

This isn’t really the type of manipulative that would be “played with” in a classroom setting, but it could definitely help students understand the movements of vector fields in a physics or higher math class that may focus on the parameterization of curves or contour integrals.

While not necessary to create the model, being able to find the parameterizations of the spirals that make up each torus could be useful in creating specific tori. These are also generally handy for finding the flow of the magnetic vector fields: specifically the ones that spiral around the torus. In order to represent the course of the magnetic field traveling around the tokamak, we found the parametrization of a spiral around the object. In the following system of equations, 30.5 represents the center of the tube, 8.5 represents the radius of the tube, and the values 5 and ⅕ are used to alter the frequency of the spiral.
x(t)=30.5+8.5cos(5t)cos(t/5)
y(t)=30.5+8.5cos(5t)sin(t/5)
z(t)=8.5*sin(t/5)
These parameterizations were developed by our professor Dr. Dan Jackson.

Final product created on 12/1/16 by TA and JG.

print_settings.Notes:: 3 Perimeters, 3 Solid Layers.

description.text: This is my fourth pulse motor and a culmination of refinements from previous versions. The last pulse motor I published was kind of slow and power hungry. This one is considerably better. I've ran it at 12000 RPM using an Arduino controller. I also spent some time tweaking a Bedini-style circuit which topped out at over 6700 RPM. The circuit is interesting too so I thought I'd share that along with the updated motor design. I was very happy that I could reduce the current draw to 7mA at 12.6V while maintaining 2500+ RPM. Very sweet. In all tests I only configured it for a single pole, but the stator has slots for a second pole if desired. Feel free to build one and comment. Feedback and observations are appreciated. Observe safety precautions when operating at high speeds.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25 Layer 0.4 Nozzle

Infill:

10% Triangle

Notes:

3 Perimeters, 3 Solid Layers.

Attach magnets to the rotor using a good quality superglue. I recommend Gorilla brand superglue with the brush applicator as this has proven reliable. Apply glue inside where the magnets sit. Insert magnets so that the same pole faces outward (i.e. all north or all south). For the Bedini-style circuit orientation doesn't matter too much but if you plan to use it with a unipolar hall sensor as the switching mechanism then plan accordingly.

After placing magnets apply superglue evenly over the face of the rotor and magnets to create a protective seal that will hold the magnets in place when spinning. Let sit for several hours before using to ensure glue is entirely dry. Place 3 drive inductors in 3 opposing faces and the trigger inductor in the fourth opposing slot. The three drive coils should be wired in series so that when power is applied they repel the magnets. The rotor will require a vigorous spin to get started as it needs enough speed to create the required voltage in the trigger coil.

Troubleshooting
  • Orientation of the inductors is significant. This is true for both the drive coils and the trigger coil.
  • If your trigger coil is too low-resistance you may find it doesn't generate enough voltage to easily start by hand.
  • If the potentiometer is turned to 1k it probably won't start by hand either.

Feel free to ask questions in the comments section.

Mix it Up

There are tons of possible variations involving different trigger coil values, changing the number of coils per pole (for example 3 per pole, 6 per pole, 8 per pole, etc). The video above was a 50mH inductor as trigger and I've tried it with a 25mH inductor (not recommended), and 200mH inductor which worked well with a larger pot for more range. I'm going to order some 100mH inductors if I can find them. If you have to choose, the 200mH inductor is probably the best starting point.

If you change the number of drive coils you may want to move up or down, for example if you are using 5 or 7 drive coils you may be better off with 10mH inductors for them as the series resistance will be lower and easier to generate a magnetic field strong enough to repel the magnets.

Also you may consider changing the circuit to run at a higher voltage. Or if you lower the resistance of the drive coils it may run at a lower voltage (I haven't actually tried this). You can even place a small neodymium magnet at the base of the coils to bias them causing them to run faster and draw more power or to run slower and draw less. Anyway, hopefully you get the idea.

• 4x Neodymium magnets - N35 12mmx3mm (mine were 12x2.8mm)
  • 3x 0912 25mH Power Inductors - 9mmx12mm (mine were 25 Ohms each)
  • 1x 0912 50mH, 100mH, or 200mH Power Inductor - 9mmx12mm (For trigger coil)
  • 1x 608 Skateboard Bearing (mine was ABEC 9)
  • 1x 1K Ohm Potentiometer (or 2K or 5K)
  • 1x PC817 Photocoupler
  • 1x BUL216 Transistor - Or use whatever you got (I just like these since they seem practically impossible to destroy)
  • 2x White LEDs 8mm (or whatever you want to use, feel free to add or subtract leds as you feel are necessary or replace the snubbing part of the circuit with whatever you think will work better.)
  • 1x 220 Ohm Resistor

Common supplies such as wires, glue, tape, breadboards, etc.

Where to Buy

The electronic components can be purchased from Amazon, Arrow, Digikey, Aliexpress, and/or eBay. It just depends on how much you want to pay and how long you are willing to wait. Can cost as little as 20.00 to buy the parts with tons of left overs for other projects. Or even less if you have most of this stuff lying around.

Part Substitution

This is experimental and unproven, but I thought I'd share my opinion on substituting the inductors with different sizes/values since it may be hard to find these exact inductors. Aside from reworking the stator to accommodate the new size, what is probably most important when determining which inductors to use is to try and match the DC resistance value of the inductors. For example, the trigger coil should probably have between 50 and 400 ohms of resistance (not sure on the upper limit here) and the drive coils should work well with 27-90 ohms total resistance (9-30 ohms each for 3). Higher voltages should in theory help drive higher resistance coils or at least that would be my guess.

You can customize this and make changes easily using TinkerCad and the links below.

Stator: https://tinkercad.com/things/bXfB11x2pdw

title: Heavy Duty, Easy Loading Spool Holder for 3D Printers (~30 to ~60mm ID, up to ~200mm OD Spools)

description.text:
After a long search on Thnigiverse for options of hanging my spools and load them into the machine, i made some conclusions:

  1. Really fast charging spool holders are just simple mast that holds the spool in place. adds some friction to the extruder to deal with, and they tend to drop the spool if something wents wrong.
    2.by holding the spool directly into machine frame, can be dangerous if the spool is tangled, the spoll can fall and drag the entire machine behind it (specially with small machines). also, the spool (1Kg) puts excesive pressure in 3D printed parts of the frame, and also, adds unnecesary movements to it, which can cause printing failures.

  2. by pulling the filament with no tube guide, if tangled, the spool holder can move respect to the machine.

I know, this issues are not new. as i got some spare acrylic sheets from the construction of my Rostock, i decided to design a simple, Threaded rod based spool holder. with my configuration, up to 2 ESUN3D 1Kg spools can be installed, with separate bearings. also, by including a Filament guide with a pneumatic 4mm fitting, the spool holder can be attached to a metallic bowden extruder, with no risk of spool holder pulling in case of tangled filament.

Parts Required:
2 x Spool Bearing (printed)
2 x Spool Knobs (Printed)
2 x Spool Holder cones (Printed) (4x Optional for 2 spools)
1 x Filament Guide (2x Optional for 2 spools)

1 x 1m, M8 x 1.25mm threaded rod (mine is a Stainless Steel rod)
14 x M8 x 1.25 locknuts
12 x M8 washers
2 x 628-2RS Bearings (8mm ID x 24mm OD x 8mm W) (4x optional for 2 spools)
1x M4 pneumatic fitting
1x 4mm OD Teflon tube (spare tube taken from E3D V6 extruder) - Lenght: separation of the spool holder from the printer. the shorter, the better.
1x 40cm x 200cm, 6mm thick acrylic sheet. (Laser cutted parts required)

Printer:

Rostock Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Not Raft required. Supports are required. some cleaning are required. Printed with White PLA. Works fine. no wear.

Assembly Instructions

both bearings and nuts should be fitted by pressure in a vice.

1.Insert the ball bearing into Spool Holders. they're pressure fitted. be gentle to avoid part crushing.

  1. Insert a M8 x 1.25 lock nut into Spool knobs. use a vice to press the nut into the part. be gentle.
  2. cut the threaded rod into 30cm lenghts (or acording to your requirements). clean and file both ends.
  3. insert a Spool bearing as shown in the images, between two locknuts (facing forward). use washers to prevent part crushing. tighten gently
  4. thread the pneumatic fitting into the filament guide as shown.
    6.. insert locknuts for Filament guide as shown. tighten gently. aligh the filament guide with the center of the spool. two or more filamente guides can be printed for more spools.
  5. insert internal locknuts, add washers, scrilyc sheets and insert external locknuts (with their washers). use a ruler to measure alignment of both acrylic sheets (parallelism is a must).
  6. in the first threaded rod, insert a spool knob backwards, then a spool holder, the spool, a secong spool holder cone, a spool bearing and a knob. alight both spool bearing into their knotches in the acrilics parts
  7. thighten gently, and you're done.

to remove a spool. loosen the external spool knob. remove both bearings of the acrilyc base. unscrew the external spool know. remove the spool bearing, spool holder and the spool. reassemble in the opossite direction.

description.text:
At the office, I make hot tea with a special gizmo that fits in my pint glass (because the original vessel shattered awhile back). A pint glass conducts heat pretty well so this sleeve helps me carry it without singing my poor delicate hand. The sleeve is just one filament wide and fits a standard pint glass perfectly (seriously, it's snug at both ends). I'll bet that if you print it in Ninjaflex, it'll be even better.

How do I make hot tea in a pint glass? Well, I use a special tea maker that I found on the streets of Hong Kong many years (decades?) ago:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2044092

If you found this useful, please share your work and be sure to peruse my other submissions which are almost as varied as they are many:

http://www.thingiverse.com/3E8/designs

Enjoy!

Dec 16th, 2016 update: Added an 80mm sleeve so that it covers more of the glass (the original version is 40mm).

Dec 22nd, 2016 update: Added a couple more 80mm sleeves: Plain and Ribbed. Oh Joy.

May 24th, 2017 update: Added another pattern that features 13 flat thin ribs that really give it a nice sleek look and excellent thermal properties. Feels like a new pint glass!

title: Modifided Z Extensions with Spacers for Wanhao Duplicator i3, Cocoon Create, and Maker Select

description.text:
These are modified from AzzA's Z Extensions and Spacers for Wanhao Duplicator i3, Cocoon Create, and Maker Select (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1444979)

Installing the original extensions will bend the side tabs on the x crossbeam and the rod retainers. These files have added thickness on the upper part of the z extensions and spacers to place between the z towers and rod retainers. There are also spacers for the original z extensions by AzzA.

Printing Notes:

I experienced problems printing out the z extensions with supports for the area that was not extended. This area turned out about with a 0.2mm difference, 18% off of what was intended. I don't know if different print settings would work better, I'm still very new to this. I would flip the orientation of the flat extensions to eliminate supports and if you want the peg version and don't want to have to sand that area, use the spacers.

description.text:
Hi,
This is a cable chain i designed from scratch for incoming TANK3D printer i am designing right now. Hence the name, as it will be part of it.

I will soon post other parts, linear stages and the whole printer, so keep in touch. I am sure you will like it.

So it may look like other chains, but its not a copy. Its a design from scratch.

About The Drag Cable Chain:

  1. Its a working cable chain up to my standards.
    I tried most of the chains designs and they had one thing in common- did not work properly. At least from the point of view of CNC guy like me.

  2. Its a very strong chain. Once all snaps in place you can not pull it apart easily if at all. Size is relatively speaking around 20mm, so connector can pass easily through it. Experience told me its better to be on the bigger side than on smaller. It is ideal for custom builds

  3. It has a minimum bend radius of ~55 mm . It is self supporting even for long distances, side or normal position. I would say up to 1m

  4. Still no ends designed. 6 ends are needed female / male X up/down/side mount for the chain to be complete. Will do that soon

  5. Its a quiet chain, even printed from PLA.

  6. Step file attached so you can split, scale up and in general work easily modifications

  7. The "No derivatives" license is for reason that if you change even 0,2mm somewhere it will have problems moving, clicking together, self supporting, strength and so on.

    Basically you could do whatever you want, hence the STEP file, but dont call it Tank3d chain. On the other side if you need sth i will customize it for you, check if its working properly and then post it here, so all could benefit from Working designs.

Here is a video of it https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8EyVTwjgCQQ

Join me on Facebook so you get first the updated files for Tank3d printer
https://www.facebook.com/groups/tank3d

Thanks!

Boyan

Printer:

Legio

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

normal 0.2mm with 0.4mm nozzle

Infill:

50%

Notes:

All of the above will be true if printed properly. As per the adjustments i show in the pictures. I print in PLA3d850 which is basically the same as normal PLA except temperature is 230C and when heat treated after it will stand 80C without problem.

Though the picture says 50% infill, most of the part actually is solid as i use 3 outside layers on top, bottom and perimeter. So 50% infill is actuclly valid for the thicker parts of it, all else is solid. And it would not make a big difference in final print time or material

So it could be printed from any material: PLA, ABS, Special PLA. Of course some Nylon will be best.

I print all with supports and rafts. Why? So my prints always have the correct dimensions. Material is cheap, Printer must never stop. Some extra work is required to clean but its well worth it.

How to clean it from raft and support and put it together

Using Simplify3d is quite easy to clean the supports and rafts. You will need pliers and sharp knife, plus some patience for perfect result. For the links to move free and the chain to extend to flat position, the links have to be very clean from support material, ooze, etc.

Dont worry about the initial design clearance, its correct if printed quality.

I connect the links together previously leaving all in hot water for a minute and click them in the water. They will click even in normal conditions but for 100% positive outcome plastic should be heated a bit. If PLA bends just straighten it with the pliers. When cold it will stay in the correct shape.

Though note that i print with 3d850 filament so hot water actually makes it stiffer after that.

Design principles

Well, it had to be working chain, not some toy. Some could think its a bit OTT but this is to avoid creep in material with time. I am designing a printer and i like to put extra attention on details.

First i printed all the chains in Thingverse at that moment. Looked at their problems. Some worked, some not, some not at all. Some simply made me laugh.

I was not very much to spend a day on a drag chain but at the end i needed it and could not find anything Open source for my standard.

The biggest problem was to click it together without breaking sth and at the same time to be strong enough. i printed links many times, so in reality it took me a couple of days and different designs to achieve the result

Redid this because the original design has the parts made of separate objects all placed within eachother and attached, but not one solid mesh. My slicer does not like that much at all. Was basically printing gaps between each part of it, making the model mostly useless to me. Completely re-modeled it as a single solid mesh, reinforced it a bit while I was at it. Original design by saschai. If you're having trouble with his/hers, try mine. Should work fine.

May further revise for additional stability later, but this is what I have for now.

comments.text:
Unfortunately people do not understand the reason to leave the top of the lead screw free. Is free by design, this way any wobbling of the screw will not put pressure to the smooth rods. simply compare the screw with an archer's bow, if you hold it in the middle and in the bottom and rotate it, the loose top will wobble around instead of in the middle, now if you restrict both ends and rotate it, the middle will wobble and that is exactly what happens when you use the so famous anti wobbling. You do not see it but the middle is wobbling and putting pressure on the smooth rods.
Anti-wobbling devices are in detriment of print quality. Engineers at Anet and other companies left it loose at the top by design.If you do not like to see it wobbling - and this is only when the carriage is moving up or down at fast speed - DO NOT LOOK AT IT - Do yourself a favor and remove those anti-wobbling things.

A few other fixes and the printer barely has any at ALL.  She's running her prints very fast and extremely accurate....  If you don't like it feel free not to use it, but I'm loving the change.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
As I said to you guys, you fail to address the real issues and eliminate the root causes of the problems.
Inertia ? True it is the second main cause of wobble and it is why I made a X carriage that totals 260g, hot end, extruder cooling etc... and manage to eliminate any play in the linear bearings !
Anyway, good luck, your first mistake was to buy an Anet, plastic frame Prusa means junk.
comments.author: Israfil

comments.text: I wholeheartedly disagree.  Honestly this printer has been one of my best purchases ever.   As i said above, she is very stable now, prints extremely quickly with no mechanical errors, and honestly I'm loving it.  How many sub-300 dollar 3d printers can you think of that can print close to 100mm/sec and do so accurately?  Can't be many... I'm very happy with my progress with it, and my choice of model.  I can think of 2 ways to handle inertia for these things.  Either reduce the weight of the moving parts, or stiffen the support structure and find ways to absorb that energy.   I've opted towards the latter option, as I'd rather not rework it if I can simply reinforce it.

description.text: "The Japanese have a saying: a man is whatever room he is in, and right now Donald Draper is in this room." -Bert Cooper Add a 1:16 scale iconic Isamu Noguchi coffee table to your Madiverse (Mad Men + Thingiverse)! http://bit.ly/madiverse

Legs 1a. Print one of each file:

  • Noguchi_Table_Leg_Female.stl

  • Noguchi_Table_Leg_Male.stl
    • 1b. Alternately, you can print both at the same time using the plate file:
  • Noguchi_Table_Legs_Plate.stl

  • Once printed, the hole in the female piece may be tight and need to be slightly enlarged. To do so, use a drill bit and pin vise to gradually enlarge the hole. Easy does it; tolerances are tight!

  • The full-size table legs come in several finishes: walnut, cherry, ebony, and ash. If you don't have the correct color filament, print in natural or white and use spray paint or permanent marker to color the finished print.
    • Top The top is cut from 0.040" (1.0mm) plastic sheet. 1a. Print Noguchi_Table_Top.svg, cut out shape, affix to plastic sheet, and roughly cut to fit using a utility knife. File and sand to final shape. 1b. Alternately, if you have access to a laser cutter, just load the SVG file and fire away!

author: TooManyMendels

description.text: Remix of the light switch cover. Should print all in one piece as a decorative light switch cover. Simple hinge. Faux push button, that really is a door that opens. Printing it now to test functionality. Just an idea for a switch cover, opens up possibilities to different designs. Also functional for parents with toddlers that love to play with switches.... Sometimes we just want the lights left the way we put them, instead of strobed simply because a 3 year old can reach...
Small footstep I did

You will need 2xM5 nuts and 1xM6 nuts to be inserted in the model while its been printed.
To mount everything you need 2xM5x16mm screws and 1xM6x24mm screw (or longer).

Feel free to edit it to your needs.

I included the model of the tripod adaptor I used because someone may find it usefull.

comments.text: What percentage of infill do you use?
comments.author: Zakarian

title: M12 mount for Raspberry Pi V2 Camera

description.text:
I have remixed the existing M12 lens adapter to fit the Pi V2 camera.
Apparently the mini connector on the V1 camera is centered whereas the V2 camera connector is offset.

I printed this and after cleaning up the supports, fits like a glove.

comments.text: This works excellent. FYI you will have to take out the existing Pi Camera Lens
comments.author: tracyaf_2

comments.text: Hello, Is there a lens on raspberry pi camera v2 by default. Is it easy to take it out. I would like a buy a RPI camera (without IR filter), and would like to be able to change lenses and add IR filter as well.
comments.author: tracyaf_2

comments.text:
Yes, there is, you'll have to remove it. Its not the easiest thing in the world, but its completely doable.
I would recommend you print a Pi camera lens spanner, such as this one : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1574661
You print two of these, one to hold the body, the other to unscrew the lens.
comments.author: GaugeTheory

comments.text: Thanks for designing this!  I've got a couple questions about it - I want to use it for a camera project I am working on with RPI.  I apologize in advance for my lack of familiarity - I am new to this.
comments.author: Rox17

comments.text: Cant say I have used any of those. I could not find the precise UV wavelength lowpass I needed, so I had a crystal disc custom cut and used a piece of heat-shrink tube to fasten it on top of the lens (leave just enough sleeve hanging beyond the filter so it wraps around the edge when shrinked)
comments.author: Rox17

comments.text: I'm glad it worked for you!
comments.author: vaqueram

comments.text: Excellent work! I had been thinking of doing something like this, and here you've already done it for me. I think this M12 mount is a much better solution than the non-threaded, reversed microscope adaptor I did to get a longer lens with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1565909
comments.author: jbeale
